repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:

Running `echo dummy | nvim file1 file2` closes the buffer for file1 if file1 doesn't exist.

Solution:

It looks the timing or order of when the buffer for stdin was created changed in 43e8ec9 such that the stdin buffer may now be created after the file arguments. This change handles that case.

Fixes: #35269

<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

comment_data.body:
er... doesn't this conflict with the test just above (which references https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/8561)? 

    if stdin is empty: selects buffer 2, deletes buffer 1 #8561

or is it different because in this case, buffer 1 is an actual file-on-disk?

based on other parts of main.c it looks like we can use `semsg` here, which helps avoids confused users. though this should "never" happen in practice.
```suggestion
      semsg("Failed to create buffer for stdin");
```
was this intended to apply to the stdin buffer? does this need to be moved?

Sorry, I should've called it out more. Difference between those two tests is where the `-` is in the argument list. In the test for #8561 it's first, in the test I added it's last. That's why the unit tests still passed even when it was failing when using non-headless mode from the shell (since stdin ends up being read last in that case). I'll update the name of the test.

The two cases are:

1. stdin buffer is first and so it's already `curbuf` (this is the case that worked before)

2. stdin buffer is last and `curbuf` is pointing to the first file argument. that case, we need to set `curbuf` to the stdin buffer while we work with it (and remember the old `curbuf` so we can restore it when we're done). So I don't think it needs to be moved (unless I've misunderstood the question)

My proposal for this one is:

if stdin is empty and - is last: selects buffer 1, deletes buffer 3 #35269

asan failure. this is one reason why the old code was using `do_cmdline_cmd`

```

=     #1 0x564319852584 in try_malloc /home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/src/nvim/memory.c:113:15

=     #12 0x564318b20f74 in _start (/home/runner/work/neovim/neovim/build/bin/nvim+0xc7ef74) (BuildId: 94f2d704be41a838937af8c98dba131aa568a09b)
```
Ok, I'll take a look. Is there a way to run the leak detection locally?

comment_regular_data.body: I'm new to the neovim codebase so I wasn't sure if there was a way to read the stdin buffer without making it `curbuf`. If there's a better way, please let me know!

> Ideally `prev_buf` could be eliminated somehow, or maybe that whole block of logic could be simplified.

I know, I wish I knew a cleaner way to do it.

title: fix(startup): keep empty file arg w/ stdin
